The koruna had different phases, including a first, second, and third version. There were significant events like the 1953 currency reform which caused panic and economic issues. The document also mentions the consumer price index increases, showing inflation trends, especially a sharp rise in 1991. The koruna was replaced by the euro in Slovakia in 2009, but the Czech Republic still uses its own koruna.

I need to make sure the summary includes the main periods, key events (like the 1953 reform and the 1993 split), and the eventual replacement by the euro. The **Czechoslovak koruna** served as the official currency of Czechoslovakia from 1919 to 1939 and again from 1945 to 1993, undergoing multiple reforms and facing significant economic challenges, including hyperinflation and a controversial 1953 currency overhaul that caused public unrest. It was divided into two separate currencies, the Czech and Slovak korunas, in 1993 following the dissolution of Czechoslovakia, with Slovakia adopting the euro in 2009 while the Czech Republic retained its own currency. The koruna was subdivided into 100 haléřů (Czech) or halierov (Slovak), and its history reflects the political and economic shifts of the 20th century, including wartime disruptions and post-communist transitions. The document also highlights inflation trends, with a sharp 57.9% increase in 1991, underscoring the currency's instability in its final years.

# Czechoslovak koruna



The **Czechoslovak koruna** (in Czech and Slovak: *koruna československá*, at times *koruna česko-slovenská*; *koruna* means *crown*) was the currency of Czechoslovakia from 10 April 1919 to 14 March 1939, and from 1 November 1945 to 7 February 1993. [S2] For a brief time in 1939 and again in 1993, it was also the currency of both the separate Czech Republic and Slovakia. [S3] On 8 February 1993, it was replaced by the Czech koruna and the Slovak koruna, both at par. [S4] The (last) ISO 4217 code and the local abbreviations for the koruna were *CSK* and *Kčs*. [S5] One koruna equalled 100 *haléřů* (Czech, singular: *haléř*) or *halierov* (Slovak, singular: *halier*). [S6] In both languages, the abbreviation *h* was used. [S7] The abbreviation was placed behind the numeric value. [S8] ## First koruna

A currency called the *krone* in German and *koruna* in Czech was introduced in Austria-Hungary on 11 September 1892, as the first modern gold-based currency in the area. [S9] After the creation of an independent Czechoslovakia in 1918, an urgent need emerged for the establishment of a new currency system that would distinguish itself from the currencies of the other newly born countries suffering from inflation. [S10] The next year, on 10 April 1919, a currency reform took place, defining the new *koruna* as equal in value to the Austro-Hungarian krone. [S11] The first banknotes came into circulation the same year, the coins three years later, in 1922. [S12] This first koruna circulated until 1939, when separate currencies for Bohemia and Moravia and Slovakia were introduced, at par with the Czechoslovak koruna. [S13] These were the Bohemian and Moravian koruna and the Slovak koruna. [S14] ### Coins


### Banknotes


## Second koruna

The Czechoslovak koruna was re-established in 1945, replacing the two previous currencies at par. [S15] As a consequence of the war, the currency had lost much of its value. [S16] ### Coins


### Banknotes


## Third koruna

| --- | --- |
|
| **Obverse**: Coat of arms of Czechoslovakia and linden twig surrounded by year and lettering "ČESKOSLOVENSKÁ SOCIALISTICKÁ REPUBLIKA" (Czechoslovak Socialist Republic). [S18] | **Reverse**: Hammer and sickle with five-pointed star within abstract linden leaf at left, face-value at right. [S19] |
| 205,779,354 coins minted from 1972 to 1990. [S20] | |

The koruna went through a number of further reforms. [S21] A particularly drastic one was undertaken in 1953. [S22] At that time, the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia had to deal with the existence of a double market in the country: a fixed market ensuring basic food availability (a remnant of the postwar quota system); and a free market, in which goods were as much as eight times more expensive but better quality. [S23] They decided to declare a currency reform effective from 1 June 1953 and to distribute new banknotes printed in the Soviet Union. [S24] The reform had been prepared very quickly and was confidential up to the last minute, but some information leaked anyway, causing a lot of panic. [S25] The night before the deadline, the president of Czechoslovakia, Antonín Zápotocký, made a radio speech, in which he lied to the nation that there was no possibility of a reform and quietened down the inhabitants. [S26] The next day, people (those lucky enough not to fit into the category of "capitalistic elements", a pejorative category which the intelligence agency used to blacklist certain individuals) were allowed to change up to 1,500 old korunas for new korunas at the rate of 5 old to 1 new koruna and the rest at the rate of 50 to 1. [S27] All insurance stock, state obligations and other commercial papers were nullified. [S28] The economic situation of many people got worse, and many petitions and demonstrations broke out, the largest of which took place in Plzeň, where 472 people were arrested.

[S3] On 8 February 1993, it was replaced by the Czech koruna and the Slovak koruna, both at par. [S4] The (last) ISO 4217 code and the local abbreviations for the koruna were *CSK* and *Kčs*. [S5] One koruna equalled 100 *haléřů* (Czech, singular: *haléř*) or *halierov* (Slovak, singular: *halier*). [S6] In both languages, the abbreviation *h* was used. [S7] The abbreviation was placed behind the numeric value. [S8] ## First koruna

A currency called the *krone* in German and *koruna* in Czech was introduced in Austria-Hungary on 11 September 1892, as the first modern gold-based currency in the area. [S9] After the creation of an independent Czechoslovakia in 1918, an urgent need emerged for the establishment of a new currency system that would distinguish itself from the currencies of the other newly born countries suffering from inflation. [S10] The next year, on 10 April 1919, a currency reform took place, defining the new *koruna* as equal in value to the Austro-Hungarian krone. [S11] The first banknotes came into circulation the same year, the coins three years later, in 1922. [S12] This first koruna circulated until 1939, when separate currencies for Bohemia and Moravia and Slovakia were introduced, at par with the Czechoslovak koruna. The koruna went through a number of further reforms. [S21] A particularly drastic one was undertaken in 1953. [S22] At that time, the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia had to deal with the existence of a double market in the country: a fixed market ensuring basic food availability (a remnant of the postwar quota system); and a free market, in which goods were as much as eight times more expensive but better quality. [S23] They decided to declare a currency reform effective from 1 June 1953 and to distribute new banknotes printed in the Soviet Union. [S24] The reform had been prepared very quickly and was confidential up to the last minute, but some information leaked anyway, causing a lot of panic. [S25] The night before the deadline, the president of Czechoslovakia, Antonín Zápotocký, made a radio speech, in which he lied to the nation that there was no possibility of a reform and quietened down the inhabitants. [S26] The next day, people (those lucky enough not to fit into the category of "capitalistic elements", a pejorative category which the intelligence agency used to blacklist certain individuals) were allowed to change up to 1,500 old korunas for new korunas at the rate of 5 old to 1 new koruna and the rest at the rate of 50 to 1. [S27] All insurance stock, state obligations and other commercial papers were nullified. [S28] The economic situation of many people got worse, and many petitions and demonstrations broke out, the largest of which took place in Plzeň, where 472 people were arrested.
